Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Methodological Training Opportunity for Politics and Genetics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The recent introduction of genetic methods into political science impels the need for training the larger political science community in these methods. Despite increasing availability of data and publications that integrate politics and genetics, very few political scientists are trained in the methodologies needed to review, evaluate, critique, or take part in this burgeoning area of research. Moreover, for political scientists interested in this growing area of political behavior, there are few avenues to pursue training; to date, no existing political science programs, methods workshops or other curricula offer (or are qualified to offer) training in genetics and familial modeling. Our project addresses these deficiencies by supporting dedicated opportunities for political scientists to attend the Institute of Behavioral Genetics (IBG)'s annual methods workshop at the University of Colorado-Boulder over the next four years. The most critical benefit of this program will be the introduction of methods for genetic analysis to a broader population of mainstream political scientists. These individuals will in turn have the tools to train future graduate students, include familial modeling their coursework, conduct primary research, write new grants, supervise theses, and review grants, articles, and other scholarship. In addition, the training will have spillover effects in facilitating cross-disciplinary collaboration between political scientists and scholars in psychology, genetics, and other fields where such partnerships have been rare. Exposing and training more political scientists in behavior genetics will also open doors to funding from different sources, and to a wider range of publication venues for scholars conducting this research. Importantly, for political scientists, this type of training may also help to dissipate notions of determinism that surround genetics research, while for geneticists, it may help dispel the notion that social science is anti-science. The long-term impact will undoubtedly be to spawn new interest in these areas, create a long-term investment in behavioral work with a genetic component, and to make better reviewers and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Only a few years ago, the idea that genes could account for differences in human social behavior was considered impossible by almost all in the social sciences; yet a tidal wave of research since 1970s made such beliefs unreconcilable. Indeed, an unprecedented amount of scholarship utilizing genetic models to expand the understanding of social and political traits had emerged and almost all of it was undertaken outside of the social sciences.

Political scientists especially, had no training or expertise in these methods and no way to engage in the discussion; as data and publishing opportunities in this area continued to grow, that absence became a noticeable impediment to the political and social sciences. The goals of this project therefore were to provide both short- and long-term training opportunities for social and political scientists to develop the skills to perform research, review articles and grants, teach and mentor at the intersection of genetics and human behavior.

From this award alone, we trained 47 students in behavior genetics methods. Arguably, the most important impact of this project has been the introduction of genetic techniques to mainstream political scientists. The combined result from those trained through the grant, both faculty and students, has led to more than 100 published articles, large funded grants and books, and at least 6 special issues of high impact journals. These scholars have shown they now have the tools to train future graduate students, include familial modeling and molecular genetics their coursework, perform primary research, write new grants, and supervise theses, as well as review articles and grants.

Exposing and training political scientists in behavior genetics has opened the door for future funding from different avenues and a wider range of publication venues for both disciplines. Interactions and collaborations between social scientists and geneticists resulting from this award has have proven fruitful in both fields, and the workshop environment has inspired more interdisciplinary collaboration. In short, by expanding the training of individual political scientists, the project has expanded the overall field.

 This training has also helped dissipate notions of determinism that surround genetics research, while for geneticists, it has certainly dispelled the notion that social science is anti-science with nothing to offer. Indeed, ten years ago, political scientists were handwringing and debating if genes played a role in behavior. Today, the conversation is not if genes play a role, but how? and what methods are best to identify such roles?

The tone, tenor and basic foundation of the discipline has changed. While the training we made available through the NSF cannot account for all or even most of this movement, it certainly accounts for a meaningful part of it.
